thread.title: Recipe: One-pot French onion pasta bake | Sainsbury's
thread.title_full: Recipe: One-pot French onion pasta bake | Sainsbury's

posts.title: Recipe: One-pot French onion pasta bake | Sainsbury's
posts.text:
Cook One-pot French onion pasta bake 
We’ve taken the classic French onion soup and turned it into a rich and creamy pasta dish with caramelised onions, oozy melted gruyère cheese and crispy sourdough and thyme breadcrumbs. This no-fuss, one-pot recipe takes just 20 minutes to prep, so it’s perfect weeknight comfort food Ready in 1 hour 5 minutes Cooking time 45 minutes 2 sweet onions, thinly sliced 2 tsp brown sugar 150g closed cup chestnut mushrooms, sliced 2 garlic cloves, minced 850ml beef stock, made with 2 stock cubes 400ml spirali pasta 6 sprigs of thyme, plus extra stalks to garnish 50g sourdough, torn into bite-size pieces 150g natural yogurt Method 1 
Heat an oven-safe large saucepan over a medium-high heat. Add the butter and 1 tbsp oil. Once melted, add the onions and brown sugar and cook for 10 minutes, stirring frequently, until softened. 2 
Add the balsamic vinegar along with a splash of the cider and let the liquid cook into the onions. Gradually add more of the cider, continuing to cook, until all the liquid has been added and cooked down. Continue to cook for another 8-10 minutes until the onions are caramelised. 3 
Add the mushrooms and garlic to the caramelised onions and stir through. Season well and cook until the mushrooms are soft. Add the beef stock and bring to a boil. Add the pasta, bay leaves and half the thyme and cook, stirring often, for 15-20 minutes until most of the liquid has been soaked up by the pasta and the pasta is al dente. 4 
Meanwhile, add the remaining oil to a frying pan and place over a medium heat. Once hot, add the sourdough pieces and cook for 3-4 minutes until lightly golden. Add the leaves from the remaining thyme and continue to cook until the breadcrumbs are deeply golden in colour. Transfer the breadcrumbs to a kitchen towel. 5 
Once the pasta is done, stir in the yogurt followed by most the gruyère cheese until melted. Spoon into dishes and serve topped with the remaining cheese, breadcrumbs and thyme sprigs. Nutritional Details

posts.title: Recipe: Beer spaghetti bolognese | Sainsbury's
posts.text:
Cook Beer spaghetti bolognese 
Swap red wine for a splash of beer in this classic spaghetti bolognese recipe. The pale ale adds depth of flavour while the pancetta lends smokiness to the beef ragu sauce. Sprinkle with parmesan cheese and serve with a green salad Ready in 55 minutes 1 red onion, finely chopped 1 carrot, finely chopped 1 celery stick, finely chopped 2 cloves garlic, finely chopped 1 tbsp freshly chopped rosemary 1 tbsp tomato purée Method 1 
Heat the oil in a large frying pan and fry the pancetta for 3-4 minutes, until starting to crisp. Add the onion, carrot and celery and continue to sweat over a low heat for 8-10 minutes, until the vegetables are soft. Add the garlic, rosemary and tomato purée and cook for 2-3 minutes. 2 
Add the mince to the pan and turn the heat up. Use your spoon to break up the mince and fry for 3-4 minutes, until browned. Add the Worcestershire sauce, ale and chopped tomatoes and bring to the boil. Reduce the heat and simmer for 20-25 minutes, until the sauce has reduced down to a thick, sticky sauce. Season well with black pepper. 3 
Meanwhile, cook the spaghetti according to the instructions on the packet. Drain and return to the pan. Stir a couple of large spoons of the sauce through the pasta, then divide between four shallow bowls. Top with the remaining bolognese sauce. Garnish with grated parmesan. Nutritional Details

posts.title: 6 Pumpkin & Squash Recipes | Sainsbury's
posts.text:
5. Curried pumpkin soup 
Warm up this autumn. Whiz up this souperior soup and if you are still in the halloween mood ( even though it was a while ago) decorate with a fun spider-web design. Spoon crème fraîche into a piping bag, pipe a spiral onto the surface and use a cocktail stick to form a web. 
You can’t beat a traybake for feeding a crowd and this one tastes divine. Tender roast chicken, chunks of sweet caramelised squash and creamy goats’ cheese – more good reasons to love autumn. Tags

thread.title: Recipe: Pumpkin and roasted garlic houmous | Sainsbury's
thread.title_full: Recipe: Pumpkin and roasted garlic houmous | Sainsbury's

posts.title: Recipe: Pumpkin and roasted garlic houmous | Sainsbury's
posts.text:
Cook Pumpkin and roasted garlic houmous 
This super-smooth houmous recipe, made with caramelised garlic and roasted pumpkin purée, is a healthier alternative to traditional dips. Its rich and creamy texture is perfectly paired with pitta chips or your favourite crudités Ready in 1 hour 15 minutes Cooking time 1 hour 400g pumpkin, peeled and cut into 2cm cubes 3 tbsp, plus 1 tsp olive oil 1 large bulb garlic 400g tin chickpeas, drained and rinsed 1 lemon, juiced Method 1 
Preheat the oven to 200°C/fan 180°C/gas mark 4. Toss the pumpkin pieces in 1 tbsp oil with some seasoning and lie on a wide roasting tray. Carefully take a small slice off the top of the bulb or garlic so that you expose the tops of each clove, making sure not to slice the bottom part, which will hold it together. Drizzle this with 1 tsp olive oil and wrap with tin foil. 2 
Place the pumpkin and garlic in the oven for 40-45 minutes, turning halfway through, until the pumpkin is cooked through. Check the garlic by piercing a clove with a knife – if it is still hard, place it back in the oven for another 15 minutes until soft. 3 
Once the garlic is cooked through, leave to cool slightly then squeeze it out of its skin. Place this in a food processor with the roasted pumpkin, chickpeas, lemon juice, remaining olive oil, tahini and some seasoning. Blitz until smooth, adding a splash of water if it needs loosening. Transfer to a bowl and garnish with the chopped pumpkin seeds. Nutritional Details
